reviews.review_msg: He's clearly knowledgeable in his field, but this is undermined by the fact that he is dismissive and condescending towards students. Questions are sometimes met with curt or belittling responses, which discourages engagement and creates an uncomfortable classroom atmosphere. Would avoid

I dropped this course after the professor sent a passive-aggressive email before I even attended, unwelcoming me for enrolling late. He told me to drop without asking if I had prior international relations coursework, which I do. No reason to be rude on a first interaction. Best to avoid.

Professor Sajoo knows what he is talking about when it comes to POL421W. Although his grading is a little bit tough, he emphasizes it throughout the semester because it is a writing course. His classes are a little boring, but if you can pay attention to everything he says, you'll be golden when it comes to the midterm paper and the final paper.

I took IS 305 with him and did not have a good experience at all. I generally like stern professors but Amyn Sajoo was straight up disrespectful. He was snappy and disrespectful to students multiple times, and treated us like subordinates. 
First Prof at SFU that I will be actively avoiding from now on, which sucks because he teaches cool stuff.

He's definitely very knowledgeable in his field. However, he expects a lot from students and grills people unnecessarily. Tough marker, but not impossible to get a decent grade. The criteria and Canvas organization are a bit ambiguous. I would recommend avoiding if you're sensitive or do not want to invest a lot of time in a course.
Maybe instead of writing upwards of 11 fake reviews he should consider the criticism he receives and seek to reform himself as a lecturer and person.

Genuinely the worst prof at SFU, he is blatantly rude with students and aggressive. So bad that he has a reputation among other staff members. And as you can see he recently wrote himself fake reviews to try and boost his score on here.

HIST151 - Modern Middle East.  Expects lots of reading, serious writing.  Goes the whole 9 yds in explaining stuff, and seems to know just about everything to do with the region - econ, pol, lit, culture, and history.  Would love to do a follow-up upper div Mideast course with him.

POL 210 (Intro Political Philosophy).  His focus on "justice" made for a totally absorbing journey.  Backpack spilling over with readings, which the prof unpacked superbly.  Passionate, always willing to explain.  He showed amazing patience for some *really* stupid questions; wish SFU had standards for who gets in.

IS 305 - "Challenging Power."  Class ran when the big strike was on, which made the content "real world" in the ultimate!  Prof was superb on how protest movements work, or fail.  And compassionate about student struggles during the strike.  Not easy grader, but feedback is wonderful.  Bonus: full after-course support for internships, jobs, grad.

If I hadn't overloaded my semester, this capstone class would likely have been even more rewarding -- and I'd probably give the prof a full 5. He was incredibly invested in the "core texts," and made me a fan of Canada's own Charles Taylor (whom I'd never read before).  Milestone: the "social imaginary" as a key way to understand the world.

LIB 489, "Human Rights & Popular Culture."  Delightful teaching style, and content that had us wonderfully engaged. His command of history, culture & the law is a thrill to encounter.  Will take every course he signs up for in the LIB Arts program!

Equality & Charter (POL 421) class.  Super committed prof who has real world experience in public policy, and a law school background.  Cases galore and got the class totally into the arguments, legal and political.  Wish we had a "part 2" semester.  Had our share of slobs who figured all opinions are equally great (even if senseless).  Chuckle.

POL 210.  Who thought political philosophy could be this much fun?  Right to make it mandatory.  Amazing prof who was committed to making *ideas* about justice as interesting and accessible as the usual political back-and-forth.  Put up with the usual slackers who are entitled and won't stop whining.

POL 210 - Political Philosophy class. Hybrid.  Zoom sessions were as engaging as the in-person.  Connected "old" ideas to current issues in an incredibly fun way -- with a TA keen to do the same.  Brilliant.  A little embarrassing that half the class seemed never to have heard of Plato (I mean NOTHING!).  Hope they remember after the course !!

POL 421W - Equality and the Charter.  Totally engaged with students on how real world cases match up with theory.  Learned more in 12 wks than I have in a whole year of courses.  BTW: if you are one of those cruisers who want a lightweight summer course, look elsewhere (it's a "W" class, ok?) instead of whining on this site.

Expected a tough class on a hyper-sensitive subject ... and got one.  Lots of reading, solid analysis expected, and class discussions that were grown-up and left you feeling you had actually learned stuff.  Prof is cool, sharp, entertaining.  Got loads of after-class chat.  You get entitled students who think they know all and come here to wail.

A memorable course (Core Texts in International Studies) to cap my major and graduate with a cheer.  Prof is super-literate and ridiculously well-informed on global affairs ... ask him anything.  The class was totally engaged in every session, a rarity in my 4 yrs here.

He got aggressive with people when they would answer questions despite saying that he wanted dialogue. 
Honestly I think it made people afraid to answer and stop coming to class. If you tried to guess to be a participant and it wasn't what he was looking for there was a lot of "Why?" and "Come on, people! Seriously? Oh, my goodness" type retorts.

extremely degrading, rude, and stern prof, i have never heard a student or faculty member say anything good about him, even other professors are aware of his reputation and arent afraid to let you know about it. Stay away unless you want to cripple your mental health. I waited 2 years to take IS350 when he wasnt teaching it, best decision i made
Has a terrible reputation amongst students. Unanimously the worst in the IS department.

I took IS105.
It was a fun course, we got to watch movies, critically reflect and discuss them. 
Dr. Sajoo gave good insight to help our understanding & helped make the learning environment comfortable in the Zoom setting.
To be honest I did not enjoy the partner assignment as it wasn't incredibly clear how to proceed and my partner had been busy.

Received mocking words when questions did not conform to his apologist middle eastern ideology. Do not take any courses with a man who belittles others, holds calcified viewpoints, and writes dazzling reviews about himself. As such an ascetic academic that he claims to be, he lacks the academic integrity when letting others review his character.

if u want to feel depressed take this class with him. He made me question every decision i made in my life leading up to taking his class. I hated myself for enrolling in his class. Do urself a favour (unless u hate urself) and dont take his class.

Sajoo is hands down the toughest professor I ever had in my four years at SFU. His assigned readings are very dense, hard and dry but it is necessary in order to understand the lecture. He can be a little degrading with his words. His assignments do not have a clear criteria. His lectures are fast is interesting.
the worst prof ever ... lectures are dry and the questions are extremely difficult

Lack of clear criteria made this course harder than it should have been. Got grades deducted for a lot of things that werent mentioned as well. Despite his feedbacks and q&a sessions, many of us felt lost. I respect his dedication to teaching and his extensive knowledge but this was one of the hardest courses Ive ever taken in 4 years at SFU.

Tough prof but with a great personality. Cares for the students, always willing to help. Very difficult workload, and group project is a major drawback because you cannot stay with friends; partners are picked randomly.

Probably one of the best professors I have ever taken. He seems to know EVERYTHING that the course is about, he's always willing to talk more and takes your opinion seriously and encourages class discussions which helped me learn so much apart from the knowledge he has but he makes you work really hard for that grade.
